introduction: Arabic letters are categorized by their 'weight' in pronunciation. Tafkheem (heaviness) creates a full, thick sound with the back of the tongue raised. Tarqeeq (lightness) creates a thin, soft sound.

always_heavy.mnemonic_en: Remember: خُصَّ ضَغْطٍ قِظْ (Khussa Daghtin Qizh)
tafkheem_levels: Level 1 (strongest): Letter has Fathah + followed by Alif (e.g., قَالَ)
Level 2: Letter has Fathah without Alif after (e.g., قَبْل)
Level 5 (lightest heavy): Letter has Kasrah (e.g., طِبَاقًا)

always_light.description: All remaining Arabic letters (excluding Alif, Laam, and Raa which are variable) are always light.
always_light.letters: ب ت ث ج ح د ذ ز س ش ع ف ك م ن هـ و ي
always_light.note: These letters are NEVER pronounced with heaviness, regardless of their vowel.

letters.rule: Follows the letter BEFORE it. If the preceding letter is heavy, Alif is heavy. If light, Alif is light.
letters.heavy_example: صَالِحَات — the Alif after Saad (heavy) is heavy
letters.light_example: مَالِك — the Alif after Meem (light) is light

letters.rule: Always light EXCEPT in the name Allah (الله) when preceded by Fathah or Dammah.
letters.heavy_example: قَالَ اللَّهُ — Laam is heavy (preceded by Fathah)
letters.light_example: بِسْمِ اللَّهِ — Laam is light (preceded by Kasrah)

letters.rule: Heavy with Fathah/Dammah, light with Kasrah. With Sukoon, depends on context (see Raa rules).

common_mistakes: Making ت (Taa) heavy like ط (Taa) — they sound similar but ط is heavy and ت is light
Making س (Seen) heavy like ص (Saad) — ص has full tafkheem, س does not
Not distinguishing ذ (Dhaal, light) from ظ (Dhaa, heavy)
Making the Laam in 'Allahumma' heavy when preceded by Kasrah (قُلِ اللَّهُمَّ — Laam is LIGHT here)
